text:
(1b) In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful
Glory be to Him whose majesty of essence transcends the impurities of forgetfulness and error, and whose perfect attributes are sanctified from the marks of falsehood and excess. We send blessings upon the pride of the Messengers and the guide of the paths, Muhammad, who never deviated from the path of truth nor ever did wrong.
To proceed, these are pages I have drafted and words I have cited from books of language and treatises of trustworthy Imams, which were authored in refutation of those who committed errors in their speech, and rode the mount of excess in the deserts of illusions, and opened their mouths with myths, and were deceived by their trifles and went astray. [This is] to manifest the truth and correctness, and to articulate what people of intellect have spoken. I have named it "Khayr al-Kalam fi al-Taqassi 'an Aghlat al-Awamm" (The Best Speech in Investigating the Errors of the Common People). Then I honored it by dedicating it to the sublime master, who is in no need of titles and names, may Allah adorn him with luxurious knowledge and increase him in honor in the first life and the Hereafter.
Here I begin with the intended purpose, with the help of the Worshiped King, acknowledging my short reach and little knowledge, asking Allah for correctness; indeed, He is the Guardian of success and guidance.

Letter Alif
Al-Hariri said in "Durrat al-Ghawwas" (1): They delete the Alif from (Ibn) in every place it occurs after a name, title, or kunya (nickname). This is not a general rule; rather, it must be affirmed in five places:
First: If (Ibn) is annexed to a pronoun, as in your saying: This is Zaid, your son (Zaidun ibnuka).
Second: If it is annexed to other than his father, as in your saying: Al-Mu'tadid Billah, the son of the brother of Al-Mu'tamid 'Ala Allah (Ibn Akhi).
Third: If it is annexed to the grandfather (higher father), as in your saying: Al-Hasan, the son (descendant) of Al-Muhtadi Billah.
foot_note: 1. (1) p. 200. Al-Hariri is Al-Qasim bin Ali, author of the Maqamat, d. 516 AH. (Al-Ansab 4/138, Nuzhat al-Alba 379, Inbah al-Ruwat 3/23).

Fourth: If it is shifted from being an adjective to an interrogation, as in your saying: Is Tamim the son of Murr? (Hal Tamimun Ibnu Murrin).
Fifth: If it is shifted from being an adjective to a predicate (Khabar), as in your saying: Indeed, Ka'b is the son of Lu'ay (Inna Ka'ban Ibnu Lu'ayyin).
Al-Safadi (2) added two other places: One is if (Ibn) occurs at the beginning of a line. And the second is if it falls between two descriptions without two proper nouns, as in your saying: The virtuous one, son of the virtuous one (Al-Fadil Ibn Al-Fadil).
I say: A hideous error has spread in our lands, which is not safe even among the common people and most of the elite, which is that they make quiescent what precedes the word (Al-Ibn) from the proper noun, break its Ba (3), and make its end quiescent.
Imam Abu Bakr Al-Zubaydi (4) said in his book "Ma Talhanu Fihi Al-Awamm" (What the Common People Err In) (5): They say: 'Allahumma salli 'ala Muhammadin wa 'ala alihi' (O Allah, send blessings upon Muhammad and upon his family). [Abu] Ja'far bin Al-Nahhas (6) rejected the annexation of (Al) to a pronoun.
foot_note: 1. (2) Tashih al-Tashif 48. Al-Safadi is Salah al-Din Khalil bin Aybak, d. 764 AH. His most famous books: Al-Ghayth al-Musjam, Nukat al-Himyan, Al-Wafi bil-Wafiyat (See: Tabaqat al-Shafi'iyyah 10/5-32, Al-Durar al-Kaminah 2/176, Al-Nujum al-Zahirah 11/19). In the book (Tashih al-Tashif wa Tahrir al-Tahrif), Al-Safadi relied on nine books, giving each a symbol as follows: (1) Durrat al-Ghawwas by Al-Hariri (H). 2. Al-Takmila by Al-Jawaliqi (Q). 3. Thaqif al-Lisan by Al-Siqilli (S). 4. Ma Talhanu Fihi Al-Awamm by Al-Zubaydi (Z). 5. Taqwim al-Lisan by Ibn al-Jawzi (W). 6. Ma Sahhafa Fihi Al-Kufiyyun by Al-Suli (K). 7. Huduth al-Tashif by Hamza al-Isfahani (Th). 8. Al-Tashif by Al-Askari (S). 9. Al-Awraq by Al-Diya Musa Al-Nasikh (M). All these books have reached us except the sixth and ninth. 3. In the original: Ba'ihi. 4. He is Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Andalusi, author of (Tabaqat al-Nahwiyyin wa al-Lughawiyyin), d. 379 AH. (Mu'jam al-Udaba 18/119, Al-Muhammadun min al-Shu'ara 286, Wafiyat al-A'yan 4/372). 5. p. 14. See: Al-Radd 'ala Al-Zubaydi 30, Tashih al-Tashif 45. 6. He is Ahmad bin Muhammad Al-Nahwi Al-Masri, has many works including: I'rab al-Quran, Sharh al-Qasa'id al-Tis', Al-Qat' wa al-I'tinaf. d. 338 AH. Al-Hariri (7) said: They say: 'Ibda' bihi awwalan' (Start with it firstly). The correct way is: 'Ibda' bihi awwalu' (Start with it first).
He also said (8): Among their illusions is that they make the Lam of definition quiescent in cases like 'Al-Ithnayn' (The two) (2a) and cut the Alif of connection (Hamzat al-Wasl). The correct way in that is to drop the Hamzat al-Wasl and break (Kasra) the Lam of definition.
He also said (9): They say to the standing person: 'Ijlis' (Sit). The choice is to say to him: 'Uq'ud' (Sit down), and to the reclining person and the like: 'Ijlis' (Sit up). For 'Qu'ud' is moving from high to low, and 'Julus' is the opposite.
He also said (10): They say: 'Ja'a al-qawmu bi-ajma'ihim' (The people came all together), opening the Mim, thinking it is 'Ajma'u' used for emphasis. It is not so because the preposition does not enter it. Rather, it is with Damma on the Mim, a plural like 'Abd' and 'A'bud'.
Al-Zamakhshari said in (Al-Asas) (11): Their saying: 'Kana fi al-azali qadiran aliman' (He was in eternity powerful, knowing), and 'Ilmuhu azaliyyun' (His knowledge is eternal) and 'Lahu al-azaliyyatu' (He has eternality), is fabricated and not from the speech of the Arabs. Imam Jamal al-Din [Abd al-Rahman bin] Ali al-Jawzi (12) and Abu Bakr al-Zubaydi (13) also considered it a grammatical error.
Sheikh Umar bin Khalaf al-Siqilli said in (Tathqif al-Lisan) (14): They say: 'Itrifal'. The correct way is: 'Itriful', with Damma on the Fa.

He said (15): [They say: Kitab Iqlidis (Book of Euclid). It is] 'Uqlidus', with Damma on the Hamza and Dal. In Al-Qamus (16): 'Uqlidis', with Damma and adding a Waw: Name of a man who wrote a book in this known science.
Al-Hariri said (17): They say: 'Qara'tu al-Hawamim wa al-Tawasin' (I read the Hawamim and the Tawasin). The correct way is: 'Qara'tu Al Ha-Mim wa Al Ta-Sin' (I read the family of Ha-Mim and the family of Ta-Sin). The author of Al-Qamus follows this view (18).
Imam Abd al-Rahman Jamal al-Din [bin] Ali al-Jawzi said in (Taqwim al-Lisan) (19): The common people say: 'Milh Andarani' (Andarani salt). The correct way is: 'Dhara'ani' (20), with Fatha on the Ra and Hamza.
Ibn al-Sa'ati (21) said in his Amali: Whatever is from the lands of the Romans and ends with a Ya followed by a Ha (22), it is lightened (without Shadda), like 'Antakiya' (Antioch), 'Malatiya', 'Quniya', and 'Qaysariya', but the common people stress the Ya (add Shadda).
Al-Hariri (23) and Al-Jawzi (24) said: They say for the plural of 'Ard' (earth/land): 'Aradin', so they err because 'Ard' is triliteral and is not pluralized on 'Afa'il'. The correct way is: 'Aradun', with Fatha on the Ra.

Al-Jawhari (25) said: And 'Al-Aradi' is contrary to analogy, as if they pluralized 'Arud'.
Al-Hariri (26) said: They say: 'Habbat al-Aryah' (The winds blew). The correct way is: 'Al-Arwah', because the origin of 'Rih' is 'Riwh', but the Waw was changed to Ya due to the Kasra before it. So if pluralized as 'Arwah', that cause is removed. Al-Zubaydi followed him (27), except that the author of Al-Qamus (27a) mentioned it as well.
Al-Hariri (28) said: They say: 'Fulan ansafu min fulan' (So-and-so is more just than so-and-so), intending his superiority in justice (Nasafah), so they alter the meaning (29), because the verb for justice (Insaf) is 'Ansafa' (to be just), and 'Af'al' [of preference] is not built from a quadrilateral verb.
I say: Al-Radi (30) said: According to Sibawayh (31), it is analogical from the form 'Af'ala' even though it has an addition, but according to others it is based on hearing (Sama'i). He reported from Al-Akhfash (32) and Al-Mubarrad (33) the permissibility of forming 'Af'al' of preference from all triliteral verbs with additions by analogy.

Al-Hariri (34) said: They say: 'Indafa al-shay'u [ilayhi]' (The thing was added [to it]) and 'Infasada al-amru 'alayhi' (The matter became spoiled for him). The correct phrasing is: 'Udifa ilayhi' and 'Fasada al-amru 'alayhi' (2b), because 'Infa'ala' is the passive form (Mutawa'a) of transitive triliteral verbs, like 'Jadhabtuhu fanjadhaba' (I pulled it so it was pulled). 'Dafa' and 'Fasada', when made transitive by the Hamza of transport (Naql) [so it is said: Adafa and Afsada], become quadrilateral [so for this reason building Infa'ala from them is prevented]. If it is said: Words have been transmitted from the Arabs of passive verbs built from 'Af'ala', so they said: 'Inza'aja', 'Intalaqa', ['Inqahama'], and 'Injahara', and their origins are: 'Az'aja', 'Atlaqa', ['Aqhama'], and 'Ajhara'. [The answer to it is that] these deviated from the [consistent] analogy [and established principle, just as their saying: 'Insaraba al-shay'u', from 'Saraba', which is intransitive, deviated], and anomalies are restricted to hearing (Sama'), [and are not used for analogy by consensus].
Al-Jawzi (35) said: The common people say: 'Hadhihi al-ni'matu al-awwalatu' (This first blessing). The correct way is 'Al-Ula'. In Al-Durra (36): Attaching Ha to (Af'al) has not been heard in the languages of the Arabs, neither on that which is an adjective, like 'Abyad' (white) and 'Ahmar' (red), nor on that which is for preference, like 'Afdal' (best) and 'Awwal' (first).
I say: I have seen many sons of this time reciting the saying of Abu Al-Najm (37): (Poetry) (Ana Abu al-Najmi wa shi'ri shi'ri...) without pronouncing the Alif of 'Ana'. The correct way is pronouncing it.
Ibn Jinni (38) said in the explanation of Al-Mazini's Tasrif (39): The origin in 'Ana' is to stop

Among their illusions is the word (Al-Ibaqah), thinking it is from the form 'If'al' like 'Ifaqah' (41), but it is triliteral. In Al-Qamus (42): 'Abaqa al-abdu', like 'Sami'a', 'Daraba', and 'Mana'a', 'Abqan', and with movement (Abaqan), and 'Ibaqan'.
Among their corrupt inventions is the word (Al-Ananiyyah) (Egoism), for it has no origin in the speech of the Arabs (43).
Among their shameful errors is the word (Al-Iba'), and the correct is: 'Al-Iba'' (Refusal), which is the source (Masdar) of 'Aba Ya'ba' (44).
Among them is the word (Al-Itman) with Ta, for it is with Dal Muhmalah (Idman). In Al-Qamus (45): 'Admana al-shay'a' means he perpetuated it.
Among them is their saying: (Mughaylan) for the tree that grows in the deserts of Hijaz. The correct is: 'Umm Ghaylan' (46). In Al-Qamus (47): And 'Umm Ghaylan': The Samur tree.

Among them is their saying: 'Rumman Millisi' (Smooth pomegranate). The correct is: 'Imlisi' (48). In Al-Qamus (49): 'Al-Iqlisi', and with Ha: The desert with no vegetation, and the Imlisi pomegranate is as if attributed to it.
Among what they are deluded in is the word (Al-Idh'an), as they use it meaning perception/comprehension (Idrak), so they say: 'Adh'antuhu' meaning I understood it. The correct is that its meaning is submission and compliance. This was mentioned by some scholars (50).
You see them saying for the famous Companion: Ka'b al-Akhbar (51), with Kha Mu'jamah (dotted). In Al-Qamus (52): And Ka'b al-Habr is known, and do not say Al-Akhbar.
They say: Fatawa Al-Astarushani, with a Ta having three dots between Sin and Ra. In (Al-Jawahir al-Mudiyyah) (53): Al-Usrushani (54) with Damma on Alif, Sukun on Sin Muhmalah (undotted), Damma on Ra, Sukun on Waw, Fatha on Shin Mu'jamah, and at its end a Nun, attributed to Usrushana, a large town beyond Samarkand and Sayhun (55).

Al-Zubaydi (56) said: (3a) [Al-Buhar with Damma is a load of goods] specifically, and it is for weight also, and Al-Jawhari's speech supports this.
Imam Abd al-Rahman al-Jawzi (57) said: The common people say: 'Bukhor', with Damma on Ba. The correct is Fatha.
I say: Likewise 'Al-Sahur', with Damma on Sin, for with Fatha it is the name of what one eats for Sahur (58).
Al-Siqilli (59) said: And they say: 'Bid'at lahm' (A piece of meat), with Kasra on Ba. The correct is Fatha. In Al-Qamus (60): And it may be broken (Kasra).
Al-Jawzi (61) said: The common people say: 'Battikh' (Melon), with Fatha on Ba. The correct is Kasra.
Al-Siqilli (62) said: They say: 'Al-Buhtari' (63), for the famous poet, with Fatha on Ta. The correct is Damma.
He said (64): They say: 'Buzrujumhur'. The correct is: 'Buzrujumihr', with Damma on Ba (65), Sukun on Za (66), Damma on Ra and Jim, Kasra on Mim, and Sukun on Ha.

They say for the person who destroyed Jerusalem: 'Bakht al-Nasr' (73). In Al-Qamus (74): 'Bukhtu Nassara'. Its origin is 'Bukht' meaning son, and 'Nassar' like 'Baqqam': an idol, and he was found near the idol and no father was known for him.

The common people say for the brother of Joseph, peace be upon him: Ibn Yamin. This is an error (78). In Al-Qamus (79): And 'Binyamin' like 'Israfil' is the brother of Joseph, peace be upon him, and do not say: Ibn Yamin.
They say for the known book 'Bidayah', with Ya at the end after Alif (80). book_title: The Best Speech in Investigating the Common People's Mistakes
text:
Letter Thā’: Al-Zubaidi (96) said: People think that the word (al-thayyib) is restricted to a woman whom her husband has divorced, whereas it is also used for a male.

Letter Jīm: Al-Jawzi (97) said: Common people say *al-jabeen* to refer to the part a person prostrates on. The correct word is *al-jabha* (the forehead), and the two *jabeen*s (98) are the sides that flank it. This is supported by the statements of Al-Jawhari (99) and the author of *Al-Qamus* (100).

Al-Saqalli (101) said: They call the material used to plaster houses ‘jeer’. The correct form is *jayyar*.

I say: They pronounce the name of Abu Al-Fath ‘Uthman the grammarian—famous as Ibn Jinnī—with an open (102) jīm, and this is incorrect. Ibn Khallikan (103) said in his biography: ‘Jinnī’ is with a kasrah (104) on the jīm, a doubled nūn, followed by a yā’. Al-Dammamini (105) said in his commentary on *Mughni al-Labīb* (106) that its yā’ is quiescent. It is not a nisbah (attributive name); rather, it is the Arabized form of ‘Kinnī.’

Letter Ha (Unpointed)
Al-Siqilli (110) said: They say: 'Humman shadidatun' (A severe fever), with Tanwin. The correct is without it.
Al-Hariri (111) said: They write 'Al-Hayat', 'Al-Zakat', and 'Al-Salat' with Waw in every place. This is not general, for it is permissible to fix the Alif upon annexation and duality, as in your saying: 'Hayatuka' [and 'Zakatuka', 'Salatuka', 'Salatani', and 'Zakatani'].
Al-Hariri (112) and Al-Jawzi (113) said: They say for the plural of 'Hajah' (Need): 'Hawa'ij'. The correct is to pluralize it in small numbers as 'Hajat', and in larger [numbers as] 'Haj'.
I say: In Al-Sihah (114): 'Hawa'ij' is also contrary to analogy, as if they pluralized 'Ha'ijah'. Al-Asma'i (115) used to deny it and say: It is post-classical (Muwallad). He denied it only for its deviation from analogy, otherwise it is abundant in the speech of Arabs. He recites: (Verse)

I say: They say for the known profession: 'Al-Hajama' (Cupping), with Fatha on Ha, while it is with Kasra. In Al-Qamus (117): And his profession is 'Al-Hijamah' like 'Kitabah'. In Al-Mukhtar (118): The noun is 'Al-Hijamah', with Kasra. Also, they do not verify its meaning, for it is sucking, and it was named so because he sucks the blood after cutting. So in Al-Qamus (119).
They say: 'Al-Haywan' (Animal), with Sukun on Ya (120). The correct is moving it (Fatha), for the origin in every source implying commotion (4a) is moving its middle to indicate the meaning of commotion and movement like 'Dawaran'.
They say for the bubbles rising on water: 'Hubab', with Damma on Ha, while it is with Fatha (121), stated in Mukhtar al-Sihah (122).

I say: [They say] (128) So-and-so was given the 'Khatabah' (Preachership) of such-and-such mosque, with Kasra on Kha. This is not from the speech of Arabs. Al-Jawhari (129) said: 'Khatuba', with Damma, 'Khatabah', with Fatha, meaning became a preacher (Khatib). In Al-Qamus (130): 'Khataba' on the pulpit 'Khatabatan', with Fatha.
Among their shameful errors: 'Al-Khajil' and 'Al-Khashin', for the correct is omitting the Ya (131).

I say: They break (Kasra) the Waw of 'Al-Da'awi' (Claims), and the correct is Fatha like 'Fatawa' (136).

Letter Dhal (Pointed)
Ibn Barhan (137) faulted those who apply the word 'Al-Dhat' to Allah Almighty because it is the feminine of (Dhu), and it is incorrect to apply what has a feminine sign to Him Almighty. He also faulted those who say: 'Al-Sifat Al-Dhatiyyah', because the attribution to 'Dhat' is 'Dhawawiyy' (138).
I say: His answer is that they made the word 'Al-Dhat' a name for the reality of everything, and agreed upon it so the femininity was removed from it, then they applied it (139) to Him Almighty. And that which we pointed to, they did not change in attribution.

Letter Ra
Al-Hariri (140) said: They write (Al-Rahman) deleting the Alif in every place, while deletion is only upon entering the Lam of definition. As for annexation, like your saying: 'Ya Rahman al-dunya wa al-akhirah' (O Merciful of the world and Hereafter), the Alif is affirmed.
He also said (141): The choice is to write (Al-Harith) deleting the Alif with the Lam of definition and affirming it when indefinite so it is not confused with 'Harth'.

And it is deleted if they occur as pure names.
I say: Among their errors is the word (Al-Riqqiyyah), for 'Al-Riqq' (Slavery) is a source that does not need the insertion of the Masdari Ya (143). In Al-Qamus (144): And 'Al-Raqiq': The slave, clearly in 'Riqq', with Kasra.

They say for the known island: 'Ridus', placing Dal Muhmalah before Waw. In Al-Qamus (147): 'Rudis', with Damma on Ra and Kasra on Dal: An island in the Roman Sea opposite Alexandria.

Al-Hariri (150) said: They say: 'Zumurrud' (Emerald), with Dal Muhmalah, while it is with Dhal Mu'jamah. Al-Siqilli (151) said: It is with Fatha on Ra. In Al-Qamus (152): 'Al-Zumurrud', with Dal Muhmalah: 'Al-Zumurrud' (Emerald). In it also (153): 'Al-Zumurrud', with Dammas and stressing Ra: 'Al-Zabarjad' (Peridot/Chrysolite), Arabized.
I say: I have not seen anyone who spoke about stones saying: Zumurrud is Zabarjad. Ibn al-Wardi (154) said in (Jazirat al-Aja'ib) (155): Zabarjad is a green transparent stone resembling ruby. Then he said: Zumurrud is a green transparent stone used in medicinal treatments. Ibn Sa'id al-Ansari (156) said in (Nukhab al-Dhakha'ir) (157), after speaking about Zumurrud at length: Zabarjad: It is a single type, pistachio-colored, transparent but quickly extinguished [due to its softness], and it was said: Its mine is near the mine of Zumurrud. It is not hidden that this is a text on difference.

Al-Hariri (158), Al-Jawzi (159), and Al-Diya Musa al-Ashrafi (160) agreed that if it is said for two: 'Indi Zawj' (I have a pair), it is an error, because 'Zawj' in Arab speech is the individual paired with its companion. As for the two companions, they are called: 'Al-Zawjan'. In Mukhtar al-Sihah (161): 'Al-Zawj' is the husband, and 'Al-Zawj' is also the woman. She is called: 'Zawjah'. 'Al-Zawj' is opposite of individual, and each of them is called 'Zawj' also.
I say: They say for the known dye: 'Zinjufr' (Cinnabar), with Kasra on Zay. The correct is Damma. So in Al-Qamus (162).
Similarly, some saying: 'Al-Zi'amah' (Leadership), with Kasra on Zay, is an error. The correct is Fatha (163).
Like their saying: 'Al-Zimakhshari' (164), for the correct is Fatha on Zay.

Letter Sin (Unpointed)
Al-Jawhari (165) mentioned the word (Al-Sa'ir) in (Sayara) meaning 'the whole' after mentioning it in (Sa'ara) (166) meaning 'the remainder'.

text:
People were fond of faulting it, among them: Al-Hariri (167), Al-Zubaydi (168), and Ibn Hisham (169) where he said: I do not know anyone of the Imams of language who mentioned that it means 'the whole' except the author of Al-Sihah, which is an illusion. (5a) Mulla Hasan (170) Chalabi, may Allah rest his soul, narrated from some Imams of language in (Hashiyat al-Talwih) that it means 'the whole', then said: And the truth is that both meanings are established linguistically. In Al-Qamus (171): And 'Al-Sa'ir' is the remainder, not the whole as groups imagined, or it may be used for it, and from it is the saying of Al-Ahwas (172): (Poetry) (Fajalatha lana Lubabatu lamma ... waqadha al-nawmu sa'ira al-hurrasi) (Lubaba revealed it to us when ... sleep overcame the rest [all] of the guards).
Imam Abu Mansur Al-Jawaliqi (173) said: They say: 'Sitti'. The correct is: 'Sayyidati' (My lady).
Al-Jawzi (174) said: The common people say: 'Nahnu fi si'atin' (We are in plenty), with Kasra on Sin. The correct is Fatha.

text:
Al-Hariri (175) said: They say for this type of scented plant: 'Susan' (Lily), with Damma on Sin. The correct is Fatha.
I say: The common people say: 'Fulan salas al-bawl' (So-and-so has incontinence of urine), with Fatha on Lam. The correct is Kasra like 'Kadir' and 'Khashin' (176).
Among their errors is the word (Al-Sabaqah) (Precedence/Race), for the source of 'Sabaqa yasbiqu' is without Ta (177).
Among them is their saying: 'Ghabat al-Suruji', with Damma on Sin. It is with Fatha, attributed to (Saruj), a city in the regions of Khorasan. Thus in Al-Jawahir al-Mudiyyah (178).
Among them is their saying: 'Sibawayh', with Kasra on Ba. It is with Fatha. Ibn Khallikan (179) said: And 'Sibawayh' with Kasra on Sin Muhmalah, Sukun on Ya with two dots below, Fatha on Ba, Waw, Sukun on Ya with two dots below, and after it a silent Ha. It is a Persian nickname meaning in Arabic 'scent of apples'. This is how Arabic scholars vocalize this name and its likes such as 'Niftawayh' and 'Amrawayh' [and others]. The Persians say: 'Sibuyah', with Damma on Ba, Sukun on Waw, and Fatha on Ya (180). It was said (181): He was named Sibawayh because his cheeks were like two apples, and he was extremely beautiful.

And in it: (The word 'Sabq' is the source of 'Sabaqa' from the form 'Daraba', and people add Ta to it saying: 'Al-Sabaqah', claiming it is the source of 'Sabaqa', so it is a grammatical error from them. Yes, it can be said: It is permissible for the Ta to be for singular occurrence (Marrah) like 'Darbah' for example, meaning one race. But whoever traces their usage knows they do not intend Marrah and the meaning of Marrah does not cross their minds at all, rather they use it meaning source only, saying 'it is like a slip of the tongue' (Sabqat al-lisan) and there is no meaning for considering Marrah here).

text:
Among them is some people saying: (Sufrah) for what the dining table is placed upon. This is an error, it is with Sin (Sufrah). Al-Jawhari (182) said: 'Al-Sufrah' with Damma is food taken for a traveler, hence 'Al-Sufrah' was named.
The common people say for the known town: 'Siwas'. The correct is: 'Siwas', with Ya after Sin. Mentioned in Al-Qamus (183).

Letter Shin (Pointed)
A group of Imams of Arabic agreed that (Al-Sha'm) (Levant/Syria) has Hamza and is masculine. Al-Jawhari (184) mentioned it in the chapter of Mim before (Shaym), indicating it has Hamza, and said: Al-Sha'm is a land, masculine and feminine. The author of Al-Qamus (185) permitted both aspects: with and without Hamza, and said: It may be masculine.
Similarly, they agreed that the Shin of the word (Al-Shitranj) (Chess) is with Kasra, and Fatha is an error (186), and they corrected it with Sin (Muhmalah) and Shin (Mu'jamah) (187).
Al-Jawaliqi (188) said: The common people say: 'Al-Shahnah', with Fatha on Shin. The correct is Kasra.
Al-Siqilli (189) said: They say: [The sun settled in] 'Al-Shurutayn', with Damma on Shin (5b) and Ra. The correct is Fatha on both. [And neither is used in singular].

text:
Al-Hariri (190) and Al-Jawzi (191) said: The common people say: 'Shawwashtu al-shay'a' (I confused the thing), if you mixed it, so it is 'Mushawwash'. The correct is: 'Hawwashtuhu' and it is 'Muhawwash'. In Al-Qamus (192): 'Al-Tashwish', 'Al-Mushawwash', and 'Al-Tashawwush', all are grammatical errors, and Al-Jawhari erred (193). The correct is: 'Al-Tahwish', 'Al-Muhawwash', and 'Al-Tahawwush'.
Al-Jawzi (194) said: The common people say: 'Shattana ma baynahuma' (How different is what is between them). The correct is: 'Ma huma' (How different they are).
I say: Among their errors is their saying for the author of Al-Milal wa Al-Nihal: Muhammad Al-Shahristani (195) with Kasra on Ra. It is with Fatha, attributed to (Shahristan), a town near (Nasa) in Khorasan. Thus in Al-Jawahir al-Mudiyyah (196).
Among them is their saying: 'Al-Shabahah', for linguists only mentioned 'Al-Shabah', with two Fathas (197). Similarly, they did not mention the word (Al-Faraghah), but what they mentioned is: 'Al-Faragh' and 'Al-Furugh' (198). Likewise (Al-Sakhawah), for the source of 'Sakhiyy' is: 'Sakha'', 'Sakhan', 'Sukhuwwah', and 'Sukhuww' (199).
Among their most hideous sayings: 'Al-Falakah' meaning poverty (200), and 'Al-Nazakah' meaning elegance, for they have no origin in the speech of Arabs.

Just as there is no origin for their saying (Tarzin) for false speech.
Among them: 'Al-Shafqah', with Sukun on Fa. The correct is moving it (Fatha). Thus I found it regulated in two authentic copies of Al-Sihah (201).

Letter Ta (Unpointed)
Al-Siqilli (202) said: They say: 'Akhadhtu bi-tarfi thawbihi', with Sukun on Ra. The correct is moving it (Fatha).
Al-Jawzi (203) said: The common people say: 'Tarsus', with Sukun on Ra. The correct is Fatha.
Al-Siqilli (204) said: They say: 'Hatim Tay'. The correct is: 'Hatim Tayyi'' (205), with Hamza after a stressed Ya.
I say: Similarly they err in it and say: 'Khatam', with Kha Mu'jamah and Fatha on Ta. It is with Muhmalah (H) and Kasra on Ta. Thus in Al-Qamus (206).

Letter 'Ayn (Unpointed) (207)
Al-Siqilli (208) said: They say: Every day its night is before it except the day of Ashura, its night is after it. It is not so, rather it is Arafa.

He also said (209): They say: 'Ajuzah'. The correct is: 'Ajuz'.
Al-Jawzi (210) said: The common people apply (Al-Asas) to the singular, while it is for the group, plural of 'Ass'.
Al-Siqilli (211) said: What is confusing is their saying: 'Uman', with Damma on 'Ayn and lightening Mim: a country on the seashore between Basra and Aden. And 'Amman', with Fatha on 'Ayn and stressing Mim: a country in the Levant (212).
I say: As for what is famous in our lands of applying (Al-Umman) with Damma on 'Ayn and stressing Mim meaning the great sea, I found no support for it in Arabic books.
Al-Jawaliqi (213) said: The common people say: This is 'Umraniyyah' language. The correct is: 'Ibraniyyah' (Hebrew).
Al-Zubaydi (214) said: They say: 'Bihi umyun'. The correct is: 'Aman', with Fatha on 'Ayn and Mim.
I say: Al-Jawhari and the author of Al-Qamus did not differentiate between 'Al-Am' and 'Al-Sanah' (Year). Al-Jawaliqi (215) said: The correct is that every 'Sanah' is an 'Am' without the reverse, for if we count (6a) from a day to its like, it is a 'Sanah' which includes half of winter and half of summer, while 'Al-Am' is only summer and winter.

I say: Among their shameful errors is their saying: (Alaniyan) with Alif after Ya. The correct is: 'Alaniyah', with Ha after Ya (216).
Similar to that is their saying: (Haliyan) inserting Ya between Lam and Alif. The correct is 'Halan'.
Among their illusions is breaking the 'Ayn of the word (Al-Aysh) (Life), for it is open (217). Conversely, their saying: (Al-Ayan) with Fatha on 'Ayn, for it is broken (Kasra) (218).
Among them is their saying: 'Ami', lightening the Mim. It is stressed because it is an attribution to the word 'Al-Ammah' (Common people) (219).

Letter Ghayn (Pointed)
Imam Abu Abdullah Hamza bin Hasan Al-Asbahani (220) said: Among their errors: 'Al-Ghulam' and 'Al-Jariyah', they think they mean slave and slave-girl. It is not so, 'Al-Ghulam' and 'Al-Jariyah' are: the young ones (221). It was said: 'Al-Ghulam': One whose mustache is growing.
I say: Among those mistaken in the word (Al-Ghulam) is Ibn Firishtah (222) in the first verse of his poem in which he interpreted Arabic into Turkish.

Al-Hariri (223) said: They say: 'Fa'ala al-ghayru dhalik' (The other did that), introducing the definition article to (Ghayr), and verifiers among grammarians forbid that.
They say to the commentator of Al-Kafiyah (224): 'Ghujduwani', with Damma on Dal, while it is with Fatha, attributed to Ghujdawan: a village of the villages of Bukhara. Thus in Al-Jawahir al-Mudiyyah (225).
Among their distortions is their saying: 'Al-Ghada'', with Dal Muhmalah, for what causes growth and sustenance of the body. It is with Dhal Mu'jamah (226). In Al-Sihah (227): 'Al-Ghidha'': What one is nourished (yughtadha) (228) by of food or drink.
The common people say: 'Al-Ghaybah', with Fatha on Ghayn, for mentioning faults of others. It is with Kasra (229).

Letter Fa
Al-Siqilli (230) said: 'Farat al-Misk' (Musk vesicle) is without Hamza, and 'Al-Fa'rah' (Mouse) of animals is with Hamza. In Al-Qamus (231): 'Al-Fa'r' is known, and 'Al-Fa'rah' (232) is for male and female. And 'Nafijat al-Misk' [and without Ha: Al-Misk] or the correct is citing 'Farat al-Misk' (233) under (Fara) for the diffusing of its scent.

Al-Jawaliqi (234) said: 'Al-Fata' is not in the meaning of youth and young man, rather it means the complete, judicious of men. In Al-Sihah (235): 'Al-Fata': The young man and the generous noble.
Al-Siqilli (236) said: They say: 'Firz' of chess. Its correct form is: 'Firzan'.
He said (237): They say: 'Al-Fustuq'. The correct is: 'Al-Fustaq', with Fatha on Ta. The author of Al-Qamus (238) permitted Damma as well.
He said (239): They say for the Prophet's sword: 'Dhu al-Fiqar', with Kasra on Fa. The correct is Fatha.

I say: In Al-Qamus (243): 'Al-Fihris', with Kasra on Fa: The book in which books are collected, Arabized from 'Fihrist'. In Diwan al-Adab (244): 'Al-Fihris': Water divider, on the weight of (Al-Fi'lal), it is Greek language so they Arabized it and used it in the collection of chapters, and the Ta in it is a gross error, and abandoning it is obligatory on all people.

because it is a craft of crafts like 'Zira'ah' and 'Hirathah', and 'Al-Falh' is splitting the earth. In Al-Qamus (246) 'Al-Falahah', with Fatha: Plowing. In Mukhtar al-Sihah (247): And 'Al-Filahah', with Kasra: Plowing. Perhaps it is the truth.

Letter Qaf
Al-Hariri (249) said: They say: I bid farewell to 'Qafilat al-Hajj' (Caravan of Hajj), speaking what contradicts speech, because farewell is only for one leaving for travel, and 'Al-Qafilah' is a name for the group returning to the homeland.
I say: There is a discussion in it, because some major linguists like the author of Al-Qamus (250) stated that 'Al-Qafilah' is the returning group (251) and the group starting the journey, in optimism for return. By this appears what is in the saying of whoever made Al-Hariri's speech a support to refute Al-Jawhari (252) in interpreting 'Al-Qayrawan' as 'Al-Qafilah'.

He said (254): The common people say: 'Al-Qustantiniyyah', stressing the Ya. The correct is lightening it.
I say: The author of Al-Mughrib (255) supports this. Ibn Khallikan (256) said in the biography of Yusuf bin Waharah (257): 'Al-Qustantiniyyah' with Damma on Qaf, Sukun on Sin Muhmalah, Fatha on Ta Muhmalah, Sukun on Nun, Kasra on second Ta, Sukun on Ya with two dots below, Kasra on Nun, Fatha on second Ya, and at its end Ha (258). He did not mention stressing the second Ya, although his habit is to mention such things. He said in the biography of Abu Firas (259) after saying: (With two dots below) And after it Nun. So two languages are summarized from him in that name. In Al-Qamus (260): And 'Qustantinah' or 'Qustantiniyyah' with adding a stressed Ya, and the first Ta may have Damma: The abode of the King of the Romans, and its conquest is among the signs of the Hour, and it is called in Roman [Buzantiya].
Al-Siqilli (261) said: They say: 'Al-Qal'ah' (262), with Sukun on Lam. The correct is Fatha.

They say: 'Al-Qatar' and 'Al-Qantar', with Fatha on Qaf in both. The correct (7a) is Kasra (263).

Among what the common people are confused about is the word (Al-Qulanj) (Colic). In Al-Qamus (264): 'Al-Qulanj', and its Lam may be broken, or it is broken Lam and Qaf is opened and Damma. It was said (265): The common people are deluded in its meaning as they use it for back pain, while it is an intestinal disease with which passing wind is difficult.
They say for the known island: 'Qibris' (Cyprus), with Kasra on Qaf. The correct is Damma. Thus in Al-Qamus (266).

Letter Kaf
Al-Hariri (267) said: Abu Al-Qasim said: I asked Abu Bakr bin Durayd (268) about 'Al-Kaghad' (Paper). He said: It is said with Dal, Dhal, and Za Mu'jamah. Tha'lab (269) concurred with him.
Al-Jawzi (270) said: They say: 'Kaffat al-mizan', with Fatha on Kaf. The correct is Kasra. In Al-Qamus (271): And it is opened.

Al-Jawzi (309) said: The common people say: 'Marwahah' and 'Marrikh', with Fatha on Mim in both. The correct is Kasra.

I say: They say for the known stone: 'Al-Mas' (Diamond), with Alif after Mim. In Al-Qamus (336): 'Al-Mas' is a valuable stone, biggest is rarely like a walnut, and do not say 'Almas' (337) for it is a grammatical error.
Among their errors: 'Al-Marthiyyah', stressing the Ya. The correct is lightening it (338). Stated in Al-Qamus (339). Similarly, they err in applying it to the poem used for eulogy, for it is 'Marthiyy biha' (340).
They say: 'Al-amru mubtani ala kadha', in the active voice form, thinking it is intransitive. The correct is [to say: 'Al-amru mubtana ala kadha'] in the passive voice, because linguists agree that 'Bana al-dara' and 'Ibtanaha' mean the same (341).
Some virtuous scholars (342) said: It is not permissible to apply the word (Al-Matruk) to one who left knowledge for a time, and said: The correct is (Tarik), and it is not permissible to be an object meaning subject like His saying Almighty {Hijaban masturan} (343), because it is auditory and analogy is not permissible in it.
I say: Perhaps it is like the saying of Jurists: (8b) Whoever a prayer escaped (Fatat-hu). And what became famous of directing it is directing for 'Al-Matruk'. As for (Al-Mashghul), there is no doubt in its correctness (344). Al-Jawhari (345) said: 'Shughiltu anka bi-kadha', in the passive voice.

Among their errors: 'Al-Mustahkam', with Fatha on Kaf, meaning 'Al-Muhkam'. The correct is Kasra, because it is intransitive. It is said: 'Ahkamahu fastahkama', i.e., became 'Muhkam' (346).
Among them is their saying for the known liar: 'Musaylamah', with Fatha on Lam. The correct is Kasra (347).
Among them is their saying: 'Al-Masraf', with Fatha on Ra. The correct is Kasra, for it is from the form 'Daraba' (348).
Among them is (Al-Mazlamah) with Fatha on Lam, for it is broken (Kasra) (349). Thus in Al-Sihah (350).
What must be noted is that the real source of 'Zalama' is 'Al-Zalm', with Fatha on Za. Mentioned in Al-Qamus (351). As for 'Al-Zulm', with Damma, apparently it is a noun from it whose usage became common in place of the source (352). This resembles 'Al-Fi'l' and 'Al-Fa'l', for they use it with Kasra on Fa in place of the source, while it is with Fatha (353). In Al-Qamus (354): 'Al-Fi'l', with Kasra: movement of human, or metonymy for every transitive act. And with Fatha is source of 'Fa'ala'.
Among them: 'Al-Mu'dalat', with Fatha on Dad. The correct is Kasra, for it is from 'A'dala al-amru': if it became severe (355).
Conversely, their saying: 'Murtabit', with Kasra on Ba, meaning tied. The correct is Fatha, because 'Irtabatahu' and 'Rabatahu' have the same meaning. Linguists agreed on it (356).

The words of the author of Al-Qamus contradicted in it, as he said in (Mada) (367): And do not say 'Madd al-basar'. And he said in (Madda) (368): And the extent of 'Madd al-basar', i.e., 'Madahu'.
Some said: People's saying: 'Al-Maqta', for the tool on which the pen is cut. He said: The correct is: 'Al-Miqattah' like 'Midhabbah'. In Al-Qamus (369): 'Al-Miqattah' is a small bone on which the scribe cuts his pens.
I say: In each of the two sayings (9a) there is a perspective. As for the first, because cutting has a general meaning applied to cutting across and lengthways and otherwise. So whoever applies the word (Al-Maqta') to something on which anything is cut whatever it is, should not be faulted, for it is not necessary in usage that it be a proper name for it. As for the second, 'Al-Miqattah' is not exclusive to the pen.
They say for the famous Successor: Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib (370), with Fatha on the stressed Ya. Ibn Khallikan (371) said: It was narrated from him that he used to say: It is with Kasra, and say: May Allah leave (Sayyaba) whoever left (Sayyaba) my father.
They say: 'Al-Mudara' is good. The correct is: 'Al-Mudarah', with Ta, because it is source of 'Daraytuhu' (372).

Al-Jawzi (374) said: The common people say: 'Nukhbat al-qawm', with Sukun on Kha. The correct is Fatha. In Al-Qamus (375): 'Al-Nukhbah' with Damma, and like 'Humazah': The chosen.
Al-Hariri (376) said: The common people say: 'Hum ishruna nafaran'. Arabs do not use 'Al-Nafar' for more than ten.
Al-Hariri (377) and Al-Jawzi (378) said: [They say]: 'Mi'ah wa nayf', with Sukun on Ya. The correct is stressing it.
I say: It can be lightened on the example of 'Sayd' and 'Mayt', and its likes are many. The author of Al-Qamus (379) said: And it may be lightened.
Al-Siqilli (380) said: They say: 'Ninufar'. The correct is: 'Ninawfar', with Fatha on the second Nun, and 'Nilufar', with Lam also. In Al-Qamus (381): 'Al-Nilufar' [and it is said: Al-Ninufar]: A type of basil growing in stagnant waters.
I say: Restricting it to stagnant waters is questionable, for in our lands it grows in flowing waters.
Al-Siqilli (382) said: They say: 'Lahm nay'. The correct is: 'Ni'', with Hamza and Kasra on Nun. As for 'Al-Nay', it is fat.

I say: They say: So-and-so is 'Nisaburi', with Kasra on Nun. The correct is Fatha. Ibn Khallikan (383) mentioned it, and said: It was named Naysabur because Sabur Dhu al-Aktaf, one of the Persian kings, when he reached its place, he liked it, and it was a reed bed, so he ordered cutting the reeds, and built the city. So it was said: 'Nay Sabur', and 'Nay': Reed, in Persian.
Among their shameful errors is their saying: 'Nazul', for what is prepared for the prince and guest. It is (Nuzul) with two Dammas without Waw (384).
Similar to that is their adding Ya in (Niqris), while it is (Niqris) with Kasra on Nun, Sukun on Qaf, Kasra on Ra followed by Sin Muhmalah (385).
People are confused about the word (Al-Nazlah) (Catarrh), so some say 'Nazilah'. The correct is: 'Nazlah', with Fatha on Nun, Sukun on Zay without Alif (386).
Among their shameful (9b) illusions is their saying: 'Irq al-Nisa' (Sciatica), for the known disease, breaking the Nun and extending the Alif. The correct is opening it (Fatha) and shortening the Alif (387). Al-Jawhari (388) and the author of Al-Qamus (389) mentioned it.
Among them is Damma on Nun of (Al-Nukat) in plural of 'Nuktah' (390). The correct is Kasra. Or deleting the Alif (391).

Among them is their saying: 'Nishat', with Kasra on Nun, for the correct is Fatha. The author of Al-Qamus (392) stated it.
Among them is their saying: 'Namrudh', with Fatha on Nun, for it is with Damma. The author of Al-Qamus (393) mentioned it.
Among them is their saying: 'Fabiha wa ni'ma'. The correct is: 'Ni'mat' (394).

Letter Waw
Al-Jawzi (395) said: The common people say: 'Al-Wida'', with Kasra on Waw. The correct is Fatha.
Al-Zubaydi (396) said: They say: 'Wahabtu fulanan malan'. The correct is: 'Li-fulanin', because (Wahabtu) is not transitive except with a preposition, [and it is in that like (Marartu), not transitive except with a preposition] Sibawayh (397) mentioned it.

Letter Ha
Al-Hariri (398) said: They say: 'Hawan' and 'Rawaq' [so they are deluded in them since there is no (Fa'al) in Arab speech where its 'Ayn is Waw]. The correct is: 'Hawun' and 'Rawuq'.
Al-Siqilli (399) said: What is confusing is (Hamdan) with Dal, Fatha on Ha and Sukun on Mim:

A tribe from Yemen (400). And (Hamadhan) with Dhal Mu'jamah and Fatha on Ha and Mim (401): A place in Khorasan.
I say: The common people say: 'Al-Hijw' and 'Al-Hijr', with Kasra on Ha in both. The correct is Fatha (402). And they say: So-and-so is 'Hirawi', with Kasra on Ha. The correct is Fatha, because it is attributed to (Harat) with Fatha on Ha. Ibn Khallikan (403) mentioned it.

Letter Ya
Al-Jawaliqi (404) [said]: The common people think that (Al-Yatim) is: The boy whose father or mother died, and it is not so. 'Al-Yatim' [among humans] is only the one whose father died specifically. If his mother dies, he is called: 'Ajiyy' (405), and 'Al-Yatim' among animals is the one whose mother died.
Al-Hariri (406) and Al-Jawzi (407) said: They say: So-and-so 'Yasta'hilu' (deserves) honor, and he is 'Musta'hil' for favors (408), and these two words have not been heard in the speech of Arabs nor validated (409) by anyone of the scholars of literature. [And] the correct speech is: 'Yastaḥiqqu' honor, and he is 'Ahl' for that.

I say: Al-Jawhari (410) supports this where he said: They say: So-and-so is 'Ahl' for such-and-such, and do not say: 'Musta'hil', [but the common people say it]. The author of Al-Qamus (411) said: And 'Ista'halahu': He deserved it, good language, and Al-Jawhari's denial is invalid. In Al-Kashshaf (412), in Surat Al-Ankabut (413): And that he does not deserve ('Yasta'hilu') what they deserve.
I say: The common people say for the sect of Jews: 'Yahuda', with Alif after Dal. This is an error, for (Yahuda) is the brother of Joseph, peace be upon him (414).
